title: Amos Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Amos chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Amos Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Amos Chapter 7.

questions.question: What did the Lord GOD form in the beginning of the shooting up of the latter growth?
questions.correctAnswer: Grasshoppers
questions.explanation: Amos 7:1 states that the Lord GOD formed grasshoppers in the beginning of the shooting up of the latter growth.

questions.question: What did Amos say to the Lord after the grasshoppers ate the grass of the land?
options: O Lord GOD, forgive, I beseech thee
questions.correctAnswer: O Lord GOD, forgive, I beseech thee
questions.explanation: Amos 7:2 shows Amos asking the Lord to forgive after the grasshoppers ate the grass of the land.

questions.question: What did the LORD do after Amos asked for forgiveness for the destruction caused by the grasshoppers?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD repented
questions.explanation: Amos 7:3 says the LORD repented and declared that it shall not be.

questions.question: What did the Lord GOD call to contend by fire in Amos's vision?
questions.correctAnswer: The great deep
questions.explanation: Amos 7:4 describes the Lord GOD calling to contend by fire, which devoured the great deep.

questions.question: What did Amos see the Lord standing upon in his vision?
options: A wall made by a plumbline
questions.correctAnswer: A wall made by a plumbline
questions.explanation: Amos 7:7 states that the Lord stood upon a wall made by a plumbline.

questions.question: What object did Amos identify in the Lord's hand during the vision?
questions.correctAnswer: A plumbline
questions.explanation: Amos 7:8 shows Amos answering that he sees a plumbline in the Lord's hand.

questions.question: What did the Lord say He would set in the midst of His people Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: A plumbline
questions.explanation: Amos 7:8 says the Lord would set a plumbline in the midst of Israel.

questions.question: Who sent a message to King Jeroboam about Amos's words?
questions.correctAnswer: Amaziah the priest of Bethel
questions.explanation: Amos 7:10 identifies Amaziah the priest as the one who sent a message to Jeroboam.

questions.question: What did Amaziah accuse Amos of doing in the midst of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Conspiring against the king
questions.explanation: Amos 7:10 states Amaziah accused Amos of conspiring against King Jeroboam.

questions.question: What did Amaziah tell Amos to do instead of prophesying at Bethel?
options: Go to the land of Judah and prophesy there
Go to the mountains to pray
questions.correctAnswer: Go to the land of Judah and prophesy there
questions.explanation: Amos 7:12 records Amaziah telling Amos to flee to Judah and prophesy there.

questions.question: True or False: Amos was a prophet's son according to his own words.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14 states Amos was neither a prophet nor a prophet's son.

questions.question: True or False: Amos was a herdsman and gatherer of sycomore fruit before being called to prophesy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14 states that Amos was a herdsman and gatherer of sycomore fruit before the Lord called him.

questions.question: True or False: The Lord told Amos to stop prophesying against Israel at Bethel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 7:16 shows Amos responding that he will not stop prophesying against Israel despite Amaziah's command.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Amos 7:15: 'And the LORD took me as I followed the ______, and the LORD said unto me, Go, prophesy unto my people Israel.'
questions.correctAnswer: flock
questions.explanation: Amos 7:15 clearly states that the LORD took Amos as he followed the flock.

questions.question: According to the LORD's declaration, what will happen to Amaziah's family?
options: His wife shall be a harlot, his children shall die by the sword
His family will prosper and multiply
His house will be blessed with peace
questions.correctAnswer: His wife shall be a harlot, his children shall die by the sword
questions.explanation: Amos 7:17 declares the LORD says Amaziah's wife will be a harlot and his children will die by the sword.

medium.title: Amos Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Amos Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God's protection during difficult times. Based on Amos 7:1-3, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God may send judgment but is willing to forgive when we repent.
God ignores the plight of the small and weak.
God always allows destruction without mercy.
God does not respond to prayers for forgiveness.
questions.correctAnswer: God may send judgment but is willing to forgive when we repent.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:1-3 shows God forming grasshoppers to devour the land, but when Amos prays for forgiveness, the LORD repents and relents, teaching us about God's mercy and readiness to forgive.

questions.question: How does Amos 7:4-6 teach us about perseverance in prayer and trusting God's timing?
options: Persistent prayer can influence God's decisions and show our dependence on Him.
Prayer has no effect on God's plans.
God will always act immediately without delay.
We should stop praying if God's judgment is near.
questions.correctAnswer: Persistent prayer can influence God's decisions and show our dependence on Him.
questions.explanation: In Amos 7:4-6, God reveals a vision of fire consuming the deep, but when Amos intercedes, God relents again, teaching us about the power of persistent prayer and trusting God's timing.

questions.question: A believer is feeling small and insignificant. What does Amos 7:7-8 teach about God's standards and accountability?
options: God sets a plumbline to measure His people, holding them accountable regardless of their size.
God overlooks small people because they are insignificant.
Only great leaders are accountable to God.
God does not judge His people anymore.
questions.correctAnswer: God sets a plumbline to measure His people, holding them accountable regardless of their size.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:7-8 describes God standing with a plumbline to measure Israel, emphasizing that God holds everyone accountable and judges righteously, encouraging humility and obedience.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and speaking God's truth can be learned from Amos 7:10-13, where Amaziah opposes Amos?
options: Faithfulness to God's message requires courage even when opposed by leaders.
We should only speak when leaders approve.
Avoid speaking truth to keep peace at all costs.
Compromise the message to avoid conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God's message requires courage even when opposed by leaders.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:10-13 shows Amaziah telling Amos to leave and stop prophesying, but Amos remains faithful, teaching the importance of courage and integrity in proclaiming God's truth despite opposition.

questions.question: How does Amos 7:14-15 encourage believers about God's calling in their everyday work and life?
options: God can call anyone, regardless of their background, to serve His purposes.
Only prophets' sons can be called by God.
Ordinary work is not valuable to God.
God calls only religious leaders to speak.
questions.correctAnswer: God can call anyone, regardless of their background, to serve His purposes.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14-15 reveals Amos was a herdsman and gatherer of sycamore fruit before God called him to prophesy, teaching that God’s calling can come in any ordinary life and work.

questions.question: Based on Amos 7:16-17, what warning does God give about disobedience and the consequences for family and community?
options: Disobedience can bring judgment affecting one's family and land.
God does not involve family in judgment.
Only personal sin has consequences, not family or land.
Judgment is always immediate and personal only.
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience can bring judgment affecting one's family and land.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:16-17 warns Amaziah that his wife will become a harlot, his children will die by the sword, and his land divided, illustrating the serious consequences of rejecting God's word.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by opposition when sharing the Gospel. What encouragement does Amos 7:10-11 offer regarding God's sovereignty over earthly powers?
options: God's judgment will come upon rebellious leaders despite their power.
Opposition means God has abandoned the message.
Only kings have authority over God's work.
God supports all earthly rulers regardless of their actions.
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment will come upon rebellious leaders despite their power.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:10-11 prophesies Jeroboam’s death by the sword and Israel's captivity, showing that despite earthly power, God holds leaders accountable and is sovereign.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 7:9, God will tolerate the high places of Isaac and sanctuaries of Israel indefinitely.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 7:9 states that the high places of Isaac will be desolate and sanctuaries laid waste, indicating God will not tolerate their continued disobedience.

questions.question: How does Amos 7:8 teach us about God's justice in evaluating His people?
options: God will no longer overlook Israel’s sins and will judge them fairly.
God always shows partiality to His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God will no longer overlook Israel’s sins and will judge them fairly.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:8 says God will set a plumbline among Israel and not pass by them anymore, signifying that God will execute just judgment without overlooking sin.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their witness under pressure. What does Amos 7:12-13 teach about obedience to God's call despite opposition?
options: Obedience to God means continuing to proclaim His word, even when told to stop.
We should obey leaders over God's calling.
It is acceptable to remain silent to avoid conflict.
Only prophesy when invited by authorities.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God means continuing to proclaim His word, even when told to stop.
questions.explanation: Amaziah told Amos to flee and not prophesy at Bethel, but Amos obeyed God's calling, teaching that faithfulness to God's word must prevail over human opposition.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Amos 7:14-15, Amos describes his former occupation before God called him to prophesy. He was a ______ and gatherer of sycomore fruit.
questions.correctAnswer: herdsman
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14-15 states Amos was a herdsman and gatherer of sycomore fruit before God called him to prophesy, showing God's call can come from humble beginnings.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 7:3 and 7:6 show that God never changes His mind once He decides to bring judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 7:3 and 7:6 show the LORD repented and did not bring the judgments as Amos prayed, demonstrating God's willingness to relent upon intercession.

questions.question: What practical lesson about family and personal consequences can Christians learn from Amos 7:17?
options: Rejecting God's word can bring hardship not only on oneself but also on one's family and community.
Family is always spared from consequences of sin.
God only punishes individuals, not their families.
Personal choices have no impact on others.
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God's word can bring hardship not only on oneself but also on one's family and community.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:17 warns of judgment affecting Amaziah’s wife, children, and land, teaching that disobedience to God’s Word can have far-reaching effects on family and community.

questions.question: How does Amos 7:8-9 encourage believers about God’s justice in church life and fellowship?
options: God will judge corrupt worship and leadership, calling for purity and holiness in His people.
God accepts all forms of worship without judgment.
Corruption in the church is ignored by God.
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge corrupt worship and leadership, calling for purity and holiness in His people.
questions.explanation: Amos 7:8-9 declares God will bring desolation to high places and rise against Jeroboam’s house, teaching that God demands integrity and holiness in worship and leadership.

questions.question: What does Amos 7:2 and 7:5 teach about humility and dependence on God when feeling weak or small?
options: Acknowledging one’s smallness before God invites His help and restoration.
Feeling small means God has abandoned you.
Self-sufficiency is the key to success.
Humility is unnecessary if one is righteous.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging one’s smallness before God invites His help and restoration.
questions.explanation: In verses 7:2 and 7:5, Amos prays acknowledging Jacob’s smallness and asks God for forgiveness and help, showing humility opens the way for God’s intervention.

hard.title: Amos Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Amos Chapter 7.

questions.question: What symbolic object does the Lord stand upon in Amos's vision, representing measurement and judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: A plumbline
questions.explanation: Amos 7:7 describes the Lord standing upon a wall made by a plumbline and holding a plumbline, symbolizing a standard of judgment and righteousness.

questions.question: In Amos's vision involving fire, what is consumed by the fire sent by the Lord?
questions.correctAnswer: The great deep
questions.explanation: Amos 7:4 states that fire devoured the great deep, symbolizing God's consuming judgment on the earth or chaos.

questions.question: What is the reaction of the LORD after each of Amos's pleas for forgiveness in the visions of the grasshopper and the fire?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD repented
questions.explanation: In Amos 7:3 and 7:6, the LORD is described as repenting after Amos's intercession, indicating a temporary withholding of judgment.

questions.question: According to Amos, what was his occupation before God called him to prophesy?
options: Herdsman and gatherer of sycomore fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Herdsman and gatherer of sycomore fruit
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14 states that Amos was not a prophet by heritage but was a herdsman and gathered sycomore fruit before being called.

questions.question: Which king's chapel and court is specifically mentioned as the place where Amos is forbidden to prophesy?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel
questions.explanation: Amos 7:13 refers to Bethel as the king's chapel and court where Amos is told not to prophesy anymore.

questions.question: What does the Lord say will happen to Amaziah's family as a consequence of opposing Amos's prophecy?
options: His wife will become a harlot, his children will die by the sword, and his land will be divided
His family will prosper and live in peace
He will be made king of Israel
He will be exiled to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: His wife will become a harlot, his children will die by the sword, and his land will be divided
questions.explanation: Amos 7:17 pronounces judgment on Amaziah's household, including disgrace and death, as a consequence of opposing God's prophet.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'plumbline' in the context of ancient Israel's covenant relationship with God, as seen in Amos 7:8?
options: It symbolizes God's standard of justice and the impending judgment on Israel
It represents the construction of the temple
It is a tool for farming
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's standard of justice and the impending judgment on Israel
questions.explanation: The plumbline in Amos 7:8 is a metaphor for God's measuring standard, indicating that Israel's crooked ways will be judged and corrected.

questions.question: How does the Lord describe His future action toward the house of Jeroboam in Amos 7:9?
options: He will rise against them with the sword
He will build them a sanctuary
He will make them prosperous merchants
questions.correctAnswer: He will rise against them with the sword
questions.explanation: Amos 7:9 states that God will rise against Jeroboam's house with the sword, indicating coming judgment on the northern kingdom's idolatry.

questions.question: What does Amaziah accuse Amos of in his message to King Jeroboam?
options: Conspiring against the king and burdening the land with his words
questions.correctAnswer: Conspiring against the king and burdening the land with his words
questions.explanation: Amos 7:10 records Amaziah's accusation that Amos is conspiring against the king and that his prophecies are too burdensome for the land to bear.

questions.question: What is the significance of the grasshopper vision in Amos 7:1-2 in the context of Israel's agricultural cycle and political instability?
options: The grasshoppers represent a devastating locust plague damaging the late crops after the king's mowing
They symbolize divine protection over the fields
They indicate a time of harvest and abundance
They are a metaphor for foreign invaders bringing peace
questions.correctAnswer: The grasshoppers represent a devastating locust plague damaging the late crops after the king's mowing
questions.explanation: Amos 7:1 describes grasshoppers formed at the beginning of the latter growth that consume the crops after the king's mowing, symbolizing destruction and judgment on Israel's sustenance.

questions.question: True or False: Amos identifies himself as a prophet's son in his response to Amaziah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14 explicitly states that Amos was neither a prophet nor a prophet's son, but a herdsman and gatherer of sycomore fruit.

questions.question: In Amos 7:15, what is the divine command given to Amos after God takes him from his previous occupation?
options: Go, prophesy unto my people Israel
Build a temple for the Lord
Return to Judah and live quietly
questions.correctAnswer: Go, prophesy unto my people Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 7:15 records God's command to Amos to leave his former life and prophesy to the people of Israel.

questions.question: How does Amos express his concern for Jacob (Israel) during the visions of destruction in Amos 7:2 and 7:5?
options: He asks by whom Jacob shall arise, as he is small
He predicts immediate victory over enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He asks by whom Jacob shall arise, as he is small
questions.explanation: Amos 7:2 and 7:5 show Amos pleading with the Lord for forgiveness because Jacob (Israel) is small and vulnerable, questioning who will support them.

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in the repeated pattern of visions followed by Amos's intercession and the LORD's repentance in Amos 7:1-6?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The structure of two visions followed by Amos's plea and God's repentance in Amos 7:1-6 is an example of parallelism, emphasizing the pattern of judgment and mercy.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'I will not again pass by them any more' in Amos 7:8 imply about God's future dealings with Israel?
options: God will no longer overlook Israel's sins and will bring judgment
God will relocate Israel to another land
God will grant Israel eternal peace
questions.correctAnswer: God will no longer overlook Israel's sins and will bring judgment
questions.explanation: In Amos 7:8, the phrase indicates that God will hold Israel accountable and not ignore their transgressions any longer.

theological.title: Amos Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Amos Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Amos 7:1, what did the Lord God show Amos as a symbol of judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Grasshoppers
questions.explanation: Amos 7:1 shows God revealing to Amos a vision of grasshoppers symbolizing judgment. This imagery parallels Joel 1:4 and Exodus 10:12-15 where locusts or grasshoppers represent divine judgment. It reflects God's sovereignty over creation and judgment (Nahum 3:15, Revelation 9:3).

questions.question: What was Amos’s prayer after seeing the grasshoppers consume the land in Amos 7:2?
options: O Lord GOD, forgive, I beseech thee
questions.correctAnswer: O Lord GOD, forgive, I beseech thee
questions.explanation: In Amos 7:2, Amos intercedes, asking God to forgive, reflecting the prophetic role of mediator (Exodus 32:11-14, Jeremiah 18:7-10). This shows God's mercy and willingness to relent from judgment (Jonah 3:10, 2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: What was the Lord's response to Amos's plea for forgiveness in Amos 7:3?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall not be
questions.explanation: Amos 7:3 states that the LORD repented and said 'It shall not be,' indicating God's justice will proceed despite intercession (Numbers 23:19, Ezekiel 14:14). This highlights the balance of God's mercy and justice (Psalm 89:34, Hebrews 6:17-18).

questions.question: In Amos 7:4, what element of nature did the Lord use to symbolize judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Fire
questions.explanation: Amos 7:4 describes God calling fire to contend, symbolizing purifying and consuming judgment (Leviticus 10:2, Isaiah 66:15-16). Fire represents God's holiness and wrath (Hebrews 12:29, Revelation 20:9).

questions.question: Why did Amos again ask God to cease the fire in Amos 7:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Because Jacob is small
questions.explanation: Amos 7:5 shows Amos pleading for God's mercy because Jacob (Israel) is small, emphasizing God's covenant faithfulness despite Israel’s weakness (Deuteronomy 7:7, Romans 9:25). This shows God's care for His chosen people (Isaiah 49:15).

questions.question: What object did God stand upon in Amos's vision in Amos 7:7?
options: A wall made by a plumbline
questions.correctAnswer: A wall made by a plumbline
questions.explanation: In Amos 7:7, God stands upon a wall with a plumbline, symbolizing divine standard and judgment of Israel's moral crookedness (Isaiah 28:17, Jeremiah 31:37). The plumbline represents God's righteous measure (2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: What did the Lord say He would do with the plumbline among Israel in Amos 7:8?
options: Set a plumbline and not pass by them any more
Remove them from the land immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Set a plumbline and not pass by them any more
questions.explanation: Amos 7:8 reveals God's declaration to set a plumbline in Israel and no longer overlook their sins, indicating imminent judgment (Ezekiel 22:20-22, Hosea 5:10). This affirms God's justice and holiness (Psalm 7:11, Romans 12:19).

questions.question: According to Amos 7:9, what will happen to the high places of Isaac and the sanctuaries of Israel?
options: They shall be desolate and laid waste
They shall be rebuilt and restored
They shall be purified by fire
They shall be hidden from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be desolate and laid waste
questions.explanation: Amos 7:9 pronounces desolation on the high places and sanctuaries, showing God's judgment on idolatry and false worship (1 Kings 13:2, Jeremiah 7:30-34). This aligns with the call for pure worship (Deuteronomy 12:2-4, John 4:23-24).

questions.question: What accusation did Amaziah the priest make against Amos in Amos 7:10?
options: Amos hath conspired against the king
questions.correctAnswer: Amos hath conspired against the king
questions.explanation: Amos 7:10 records Amaziah accusing Amos of conspiracy against King Jeroboam, reflecting opposition prophets often faced (1 Kings 18:17, Jeremiah 26:8-11). This highlights the conflict between true prophecy and political power (Acts 4:18-20).

questions.question: What fate did Amos predict for Jeroboam and Israel in Amos 7:11?
options: Jeroboam shall die by the sword and Israel be led captive
Jeroboam shall repent and be saved
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam shall die by the sword and Israel be led captive
questions.explanation: Amos 7:11 prophesies Jeroboam's death by the sword and Israel's captivity, affirming God's judgment for sin (2 Kings 15:29, 2 Chronicles 28:19). This fits the biblical pattern of punishment for covenant unfaithfulness (Deuteronomy 28:36-37, Luke 21:20-24).

questions.question: What was Amaziah’s instruction to Amos in Amos 7:12?
options: Go to Judah and prophesy there
questions.correctAnswer: Go to Judah and prophesy there
questions.explanation: Amos 7:12 records Amaziah telling Amos to flee to Judah and prophesy there, showing political attempts to silence prophetic truth (Jeremiah 26:20-23, Ezekiel 3:17). This illustrates the tension between God's word and human authority (Acts 5:29).

questions.question: Why did Amaziah say Amos should not prophesy at Bethel according to Amos 7:13?
options: Because it is the king's chapel and court
Because it was a place of pagan worship
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is the king's chapel and court
questions.explanation: Amos 7:13 states Bethel was the king's chapel and court, implying political control over worship and rejection of prophetic critique (1 Kings 12:28-29, Hosea 4:15). This reveals conflict between true prophetic authority and state religion (Matthew 23:13).

questions.question: What was Amos’s occupation before God called him to prophesy, as stated in Amos 7:14?
options: Herdman and gatherer of sycamore fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Herdman and gatherer of sycamore fruit
questions.explanation: Amos 7:14 identifies Amos as a herdsman and sycamore gatherer before his prophetic call, showing God’s use of ordinary people (Jeremiah 1:5, 1 Corinthians 1:27-29). This highlights divine calling beyond religious elites (Exodus 3:1-12).

questions.question: How did Amos describe his prophetic calling in Amos 7:15?
options: The LORD took me as I followed the flock and said, Go prophesy
I was appointed by the priests
I sought the office of prophet
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD took me as I followed the flock and said, Go prophesy
questions.explanation: Amos 7:15 reveals God's sovereign calling of Amos, emphasizing divine initiative in prophecy (Isaiah 6:8, Jeremiah 1:4-10). This shows that prophetic ministry is a divine commission, not human ambition (Ephesians 4:11-12).

questions.question: What did God declare would happen to Amaziah's family and land in Amos 7:17?
options: His wife shall be a harlot, children slain, land divided, and he will die in a polluted land
He will be blessed with many descendants
His family will prosper and live in peace
questions.correctAnswer: His wife shall be a harlot, children slain, land divided, and he will die in a polluted land
questions.explanation: Amos 7:17 pronounces severe judgment on Amaziah’s family and land, illustrating consequences of opposing God's messenger (2 Samuel 12:10-12, Jeremiah 13:22). This underscores the seriousness of rejecting God's word (Hebrews 10:28-31).
